translated: Jātaka
The Collection of Eight
The Chapter on Kaccāna
The Gaṅgāmālā Birth Story 🔽The earth is ablaze,
the earth is covered with embers,
but you sing and play,

original: na taṁ tapati ātapo.🔽Uddhaṁ tapati ādicco,
analyzed: na tam tapati ātapo  uddham tapati ādiccaḥ
translated: the heat doesn’t bother you. 🔽The sun burns above,
the sand burns below,
but you sing and play,
the heat doesn’t bother you.”
“The heat doesn’t bother me,
but the heat bothers me.
There are various things, King,
that burn me, not the heat.”
“I’ve seen the root of sensual desire:
it’s from intention that sensual desire arises.
I won’t intend it,
and in this way, sensual desire, you won’t exist.”
“Even a little sensual desire is too much;
one isn’t satisfied with much.
The talk of fools is endless;
avoid the world.”
“This is the fruit of little action,
Udaya has come to great success.
It’s a good gain for the student
who has gone forth, giving up sensual desire.”

analyzed: tapasā pajahanti pāpa kamma  tapasā nhāpita kumbhakāra bhāva
translated: “Through effort one gives up bad deeds, 🔽through effort one gives up being a barber or a potter.
Through effort, having overcome Gaṅgāmālā,
and then addressed Brahmadatta by name.”
“You see, Mother, right here and now,
the result of his patience and gentleness:
he is worshipped by all the people,

analyzed: tam vandāma sa rājikā sa maccā
translated: so we, with the king, pay homage to him.”
“Do not say anything against Gaṅgamālin,
who is training in the path of the sages.
For he has crossed the ocean,

analyzed: yam taritvā caranti vīta sokā ati
translated: having crossed which the sorrowless ones go about.”
The Gaṅgamālin Jātaka (5th: medium)
